headline: Citizens Financial Group Announces Redemption of Subordinated Notes
summary: PROVIDENCE, R.I., January 26, 2026--Citizens Financial Group, Inc. (NYSE: CFG) today announced the redemption on February 11, 2026, of all of its outstanding 4.300% Fixed Rate Reset Subordinated Notes due February 11, 2031 (CUSIP No. 174610BA2), all of its outstanding 3.750% Fixed Rate Reset Subordinated Notes due February 11, 2031 (CUSIP No. 174610AY1), and all of its outstanding 4.350% Fixed Rate Reset Subordinated Notes due February 11, 2031 (CUSIP No. 174610BC8) (collectively, the "Notes").

headline: Webster Financial Q4 Earnings Top Estimates on Higher NII, Stock Down
summary: WBS' Q4 results benefit from a rise in NII and fee income. The stock lost 3.2% due to higher expenses and margin pressure despite loan and deposit growth.

raw.summary: WBS' Q4 results benefit from a rise in NII and fee income. The stock lost 3.2% due to higher expenses and margin pressure despite loan and deposit growth.

headline: Navient Gears Up for Q4 Earnings: What's in Store for the Stock?
summary: NAVI's Q4 results, scheduled to report on Jan. 28, are likely to have witnessed revenue pressure, while higher earnings and cost-control initiatives offer support.

raw.headline: Navient Gears Up for Q4 Earnings: What's in Store for the Stock?
raw.summary: NAVI's Q4 results, scheduled to report on Jan. 28, are likely to have witnessed revenue pressure, while higher earnings and cost-control initiatives offer support.

headline: How Analysts Are Reframing The Story For Citizens Financial Group (CFG)
summary: Citizens Financial Group is back in focus after analysts reset their price target, putting fresh attention on how the market is framing the stock today. The shift in target reflects evolving expectations and new information that is reshaping the story investors attach to Citizens Financial Group. Stay with this article to see how you can keep up with these narrative changes as they happen. Analyst Price Targets don't always capture the full story. headline: 3 Mid-Cap Stocks with Open Questions
summary: Many investors pay attention to mid-cap stocks because they have established business models and expansive market opportunities. However, their paths to becoming $100 billion corporations are ripe with competition, ranging from giants with vast resources to agile upstarts eager to disrupt the status quo.
